context: <b3_0>Infants <a0_0>do not have the language ability to report on their memories<b3_0/><a0_0/> and so verbal reports cannot be used to assess very young children’s memory. Throughout the years, however<a1_0>, <b7_0>researchers have adapted and developed a <b5_0>number of measures for assessing both infants’ recognition memory and their recall memory<b7_0/><b5_0/>.<a1_0/> <b4_0>Habituation and operant conditioning<b4_0/> techniques have been used to assess infants’ recognition memory and the deferred and <a2_0><b6_0>elicited imitation techniques<b6_0/><a2_0/> have been used to assess infants’ recall memory.
